sijanLeadership.title: Lance P. Sijan Leadership Award
sijanLeadership.content: Established in 1981 and named after Captain Lance P. Sijan, the first U.S. Air Force Academy graduate to receive the Medal of Honor. This prestigious award recognizes individuals who have demonstrated the highest qualities of leadership in their professional performance and personal conduct.
bullets: Demonstrates outstanding leadership abilities in the performance of duties and conduct of personal life
Available to both officer and enlisted members across four categories (Company Grade Officer, Field Grade Officer, Senior NCO, Junior NCO)
Recipients are entitled to wear the Air Force Recognition Ribbon
One of the Air Force's most prestigious leadership awards

leoMarquez.title: Lt Gen Leo Marquez Maintenance Excellence Award
leoMarquez.content: Named after Lt Gen Leo Marquez, known as the 'Godfather' of Air Force maintenance. This award recognizes maintainers who have demonstrated the highest degree of sustained job performance, job knowledge, job efficiency and results in maintenance operations.
bullets: Recognizes excellence in aircraft, munitions/missile, and communications-electronics maintenance
Criteria include sustained job performance, job knowledge, job efficiency and results
Demonstrates direct sortie generation involvement and mission impact
Awarded at multiple levels: unit, MAJCOM, and Air Force-wide
Honors military and civilian maintenance personnel who exceed standards in their career field

quarterlyAnnual.title: Quarterly / Annual Award
quarterlyAnnual.content: Standard recognition program at flight, squadron, group, wing, MAJCOM and Air Force levels. Recognizes outstanding performance during quarterly or annual periods across various categories of personnel.
bullets: Categories typically include: Airman, NCO, SNCO, CGO, FGO, First Sergeant, and Civilian
Evaluation criteria: Leadership and Job Performance in Primary Duty, Significant Self-Improvement, Base or Community Involvement
Nominations submitted on AF Form 1206 with specific line limitations by level
Quarterly awards typically use 9-11 lines; Annual awards typically use 18 lines of justification
Recognizes well-rounded Airmen demonstrating excellence across multiple areas

msm.title: Meritorious Service Medal (MSM)
msm.content: Established by Executive Order 11448 on January 16, 1969. Awarded for outstanding meritorious achievement or service to the United States. Originally created as the counterpart to the Bronze Star Medal for recognition of meritorious non-combat service.
bullets: Recognizes outstanding non-combat meritorious achievement or service
Typically awarded to field grade officers and senior enlisted personnel
Since 2003, may be awarded for service in combat zones for non-combat achievements (retroactive to September 11, 2001)
Approval authority typically rests with first O-6 or above in chain of command
Often used for end-of-tour and retirement recognition for exceptional service

afcm.title: Air Force Commendation Medal (AFCM)
afcm.content: Established March 28, 1958 by Secretary of the Air Force James H. Douglas, Jr. A mid-level decoration recognizing sustained acts of heroism or meritorious service. Now known as the Air and Space Commendation Medal (effective November 16, 2020).
bullets: Awarded for heroism, outstanding achievement, or meritorious service not of sufficient nature to justify a higher award
Must be signed by Colonel (O-6) or equivalent and above
Not awarded to general or flag officer grades (O-7 and above)
Emphasis on award to outstanding company grade officers and junior NCOs
May include Valor (V), Combat (C), or Remote (R) devices for specific circumstances

afam.title: Air Force Achievement Medal (AFAM)
afam.content: Established October 12, 1980 by Secretary of the Air Force Hans M. Mark. Recognizes outstanding achievement or meritorious service by junior personnel that does not meet the requirements for the Commendation Medal. Now known as the Air and Space Achievement Medal (effective November 16, 2020).
bullets: Awarded to junior personnel: officers at O-4 and below, enlisted at E-6 and below
Recognizes outstanding achievement or meritorious service rendered on behalf of the Air Force
No more than one AFAM may be awarded during a 1-year period except under extraordinary circumstances
Not awarded for aerial achievement or retirement
Award authority may be delegated to wing or equivalent commanders (O-6 and above)

custom.title: Custom Award
custom.content: Please refer to your specific MAJCOM or Wing guidance.
bullets: Custom criteria as defined by authority

outstandingAirman.title: Outstanding Airman of the Year
outstandingAirman.content: Sponsored by the Air Force Association, this award recognizes 12 outstanding enlisted members annually who have distinguished themselves through exceptional leadership, job performance, and community involvement.
bullets: Recognizes 12 outstanding enlisted Airmen across the Air Force annually
Selected from MAJCOM-level annual award winners
Criteria include leadership, job performance, significant self-improvement, and community involvement
One of the Air Force's most prestigious enlisted recognition programs
Winners represent the highest caliber of enlisted performance across the service

mackayTrophy.title: Mackay Trophy
mackayTrophy.content: Recognizes the most meritorious flight of the year by an Air Force person, persons, or organization.
bullets: Awarded annually for the most meritorious flight of the year
Considers flights that demonstrate extraordinary skill, innovation, or importance to national defense
May be awarded to individuals, crews, or organizations
One of the Air Force's oldest and most prestigious aviation awards
Criteria focus on exceptional aeronautical achievement with significant impact

cheneyAward.title: Cheney Award
cheneyAward.content: Recognizes an act of valor, extreme fortitude, or self-sacrifice in a humanitarian interest, performed in connection with aircraft.
bullets: Awarded for acts of valor, extreme fortitude, or self-sacrifice
Must be performed in connection with aircraft operations
Recognizes humanitarian interests and life-saving actions
One of the Air Force's most distinguished valor and humanitarian awards
Named after Lieutenant William H. Cheney

lewAllenTrophy.title: Lew Allen Trophy
lewAllenTrophy.content: Annual award recognizing excellence in sortie generation, technical expertise, and attention to detail in aircraft, munitions, or missile maintenance.
bullets: Two categories: sortie generation excellence and technical expertise/attention to detail
Recognizes maintainers who demonstrate superior performance in maintenance operations
Named after General Lew Allen Jr., former Air Force Chief of Staff
Awarded at MAJCOM and Air Force levels
Emphasizes both operational readiness and maintenance quality

firstSergeantOfTheYear.title: First Sergeant of the Year
firstSergeantOfTheYear.content: Recognizes the most outstanding First Sergeant in the Air Force who exemplifies leadership, mentorship, and care for Airmen.
bullets: Selected from MAJCOM First Sergeant of the Year winners
Criteria include leadership of enlisted force, unit morale and welfare programs
Demonstrates exceptional care for Airmen and their families
Selected through competitive board process at Air Force level
Represents the highest standard of First Sergeant leadership and performance

afsocSraJulianScholtenIsrOperator.title: AFSOC Sra Julian S. Scholten ISR Operator of the Year
afsocSraJulianScholtenIsrOperator.content:
Specific Purpose: To identify and recognize the most outstanding ISR member directly supporting/enabling Air Force Special Operations combat operations.

Eligibility: Assigned to Air Force Special Operations Command (AFSOC) or a direct enabling unit and directly supported Special Operations combat missions during the award period. Possess one of the following ISR or ISR-related Air Force Specialty Codes: 14N, 1A8, 1N0, 1N1A, 1N2A, 1N2C, 1N3 (all), 1N4A, 1N4B, 1N7, 1N8, 1U0, or 9S1. Eligible grades: Company Grade Officer (O-1 through O-3) and Enlisted Grades (E-1 through E-6) will compete for a single award.

Nomination Criteria: Nomination packages will cover the preceding calendar year (1 January–31 December). Each wing or group may nominate one individual. The SIO of each wing, group, or squadron may submit one nomination for each category of this award. Wings and Groups must aggregate awards and submit one nomination for all subordinate units.

Nomination should include: One PDF AF Form 1206 for award submission (use the current version from AF e-publishing). Limit the award nomination narrative to 19 typed, single-spaced lines, including the heading — Outstanding Leadership and Performance under Combat Conditions. Use narrative-style performance statements (each statement must include an action and at least one of: impact or result). Use 12-pitch Times New Roman font. Acronyms permitted but must be spelled out on the AF Form 1206 continuation page. Do NOT include community service, professional military education, or other education accomplishments.
bullets: Identifies the award's purpose: recognize the most outstanding ISR member directly enabling AFSOC combat operations
Eligibility limited to personnel assigned to AFSOC or direct enabling units who directly supported Special Operations combat missions during the award period
Eligible grades: Company Grade Officers (O-1–O-3) and Enlisted (E-1–E-6) compete for a single award
Nomination window: previous calendar year (1 Jan–31 Dec); one nomination per wing/group; SIO may submit one nomination per category

Submission: single PDF AF Form 1206 (19 typed single-spaced lines incl. heading); narrative-style statements only; 12-pitch Times New Roman; acronyms spelled out on continuation page; exclude community service and PME
